title: Serie A news: Juventus chief insists Cristiano Ronaldo is 'happy' in Turin
text:
Juventus sporting director Fabio Paratici has insisted that Cristiano Ronaldo will not leave the club before the end of his contract.

Recent reports suggested that the 34-year-old could leave the Italian champions soon but Paratici put the speculation to bed by claiming their star man is happy at in Turin.

Ronaldo is contracted to Juve until 2022 after completing his £100million move from Real Madrid in the summer of 2018 and Paratici is adamant that he will see out the remainder of his current deal.

Juventus chief Fabio Paratici insists Cristiano Ronaldo won't be leaving the club anytime soon

'He is very focused on his current objectives, I do not believe in the slightest that he will leave at the end of the season or later,' Paratici said.

'He is under contract: we are very happy with him and he is happy at Juventus.'

Ronaldo incredibly scored his 700th competitive goal in Portugal's 2-1 defeat to Ukraine on Monday night as he netted a 72nd-minute penalty at the Olympic Stadium.

While the result meant Portugal practically concede first place in their Euro 2020 qualifying group to Ukraine, all the talk post-match was of Ronaldo's astonishing feat.

Paratici, Juventus' sporting director, says the Portuguese talisman is 'happy' in Turin

'Not just anyone can reach this figure,' Ronaldo told reporters.

'Thank you to my team-mates, colleagues and coaches who have helped me to become the player I am.

'I am disappointed that we didn't win, but proud of the team.'

The five-time Ballon d'Or winner is the sixth player in the history of the game to score 700 career goals or more, joining the likes of Romario and Pele.

Ronaldo converted a second-half penalty on Monday to bring his career goals tally to 700

Ronaldo celebrates his strike, but it wasn't enough as Ukraine ran out 2-1 winners in Kiev

RONALDO'S 700 CAREER GOALS Sporting Lisbon (2002-2003): Five goals in 31 appearances

Five goals in 31 appearances Manchester United (2003-2009): 118 goals in 292 appearances

118 goals in 292 appearances Real Madrid (2009-2018): 450 goals in 438 appearances

450 goals in 438 appearances Juventus (2018-present): 32 goals in 51 appearances

32 goals in 51 appearances Portugal (2003-present): 95 in 162 appearances

His great rival Lionel Messi trails him on 672, but Ronaldo himself has some way to go if he wants to break the all-time record - former Czech Republic forward Josef Bican notched a staggering 800 goals between 1931 and 1950.

'How many records do I have? I don't know,' Ronaldo continued.

'I have to enjoy the moment and thank those who helped me reach this impressive mark.

'Records come naturally - I don't go looking for them, records come looking for me! Without having an obsession, they happen naturally.'
description: Recent reports suggested that the 34-year-old could leave the Italian champions soon but Paratici put the speculation to bed by claiming their star man is 'happy' at the club.
